Understanding various useful topics

Differential co-moving volume element

Differential co-moving volume element is used in the integrand of the rate calculation, see Equation 1.

\[\begin{split}\begin{equation} \begin{split} \mathcal{R}_U &= \int_{z_{min}}^{z_{max}} R(z_s) P(obs|z_s) \frac{1}{(1+z_s)} \frac{dV_c}{dz_s} dz_s \\ \end{split} \tag{1} \end{equation}\end{split}\]

Let’s try to understand it in a simple way. I will build the knowledge from the scratch. This involves understanding the following topic:

Volume Element with Respect to Solid Angle in Spherical Coordinates

The volume element in terms of solid angle is given by:

\[dV_{\Omega} = r^2 dr d\Omega\]

where \(d\Omega = \sin \theta \, d\theta \, d\phi\) is the differential solid angle.

You can also write the volume element in terms of spherical coordinates as follows,

\[dV_{\Omega} = r^2 \sin \theta \, dr \, d\theta \, d\phi\]

Let’s try a simple example to find the total volume of the observable universe. We will use co-moving coordinates. I exploit the spherical symmetry of the universe to simplify the calculation.

\[\begin{split}\begin{equation} \begin{split} V &= \int d\mathcal{V}_c \\ &= \int \frac{d\mathcal{V}_c}{d\Omega\, dz} d\Omega\, dz \\ &= \int \frac{d\mathcal{V}_c}{d\Omega\, dz}\left( \int_{entire\;sky} d\Omega\right) dz \\ &= \int \frac{d\mathcal{V}_c}{d\Omega\, dz} 4\pi dz \\ \end{split} \end{equation}\end{split}\]

\(\frac{d\mathcal{V}_c}{d\Omega\, dz}\) is called the differential co-moving volume element. In general cosmological terms it is calculated as the volume element at a given redshift per unit solid angle per unit redshift. You can generate it’s value using the astropy package. Note that differential co-moving volume element is only a function of redshift. If you compare this with Equation A1 of llows the model presented in WIERDA et al. 2021, you will see that \(\frac{dV_c}{\, dz}\) is defined as the differential co-moving volume, without explicitly mentioning the solid angle, which is assumed to be already taken into account. Likewise, I will also assume the following,

\[\begin{equation} \begin{split} \frac{dV_c}{dz} &= 4\pi \frac{d\mathcal{V}_c}{d\Omega\, dz} \end{split} \tag{2} \end{equation}\]

It is evident from rate derivation that the differential co-moving volume element is used in the integrand of the rate calculation. In that regard, one can also consider the integration is wrt to infinitesimal spherical volume shell, given by \(\frac{dV_c}{dz_s} dz_s\).
